content.description: Figure 1. Amino acid sequences of certain dehydrogenase enzymes in different species
content.question: Portions of the amino acid sequences of some dehydrogenase enzymes found in bacteria, yeast, corn, horses, and sheep are shown in Figure 1. Each letter represents a different amino acid in the sequence. Based on Figure 1, which of the following conclusions about the enzymes is most likely correct?

choices.label: Corn and horse dehydrogenase enzymes arose separately during each organismâ€™s evolution and now exhibit strong sequence similarity as a result of their similar catalytic roles.
These enzymes all evolved from a common prokaryotic dehydrogenase enzyme, so they exhibit regions of sequence similarity.
Any evolutionary relationship is unlikely, because there is little sequence similarity between these enzymes.
No conclusion can be drawn based on amino acid sequence, because there are twenty amino acids and only four nucleotides.

content.answer: These enzymes all evolved from a common prokaryotic dehydrogenase enzyme, so they exhibit regions of sequence similarity.

skill.text: 2.C: Explain how biological models relate to larger principles, concepts, processes, systems, or theories.
